reviewText:
I bought the game during the wintersale of 2015.
I used to have the old 2008 Risk which I played for many hours.
Now I picked this one up and I must say I am very stisfied with the product.

You get 2 types of gameplay:
there is the classic Risk which has mostly the same rules as the old one has except for some animations that have been added to the bottom while in battle.
And then you have got the campaign mode which has 5 chapters and are all preceded by a very cute animated cartoon, about a war which keeps escalating between generals, cats, AI and others Which made me smile each time.
I do believe they were sitting on a little goldmine there and could have added a longer campaign.

You can also start a custom game which unlocks more maps after each campaign chapter you have beaten.
The only problem that I have encountered is that sometimes while playing normal risk, the game refuses to invade a certain terratory and you must invade with a different region first before it responds. ( Maybe a fix if the developers read this)

Overall definitily a must have if you are a Risk fan.
You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Risk Factions is a small change to the Original Classic. It has too different modes: Risk & Risk Factions. Risk: Is the original game with no fancy art basic but still true to its routs. Risk Factions: Is a more dumbed down version which is alot more simple and adds a few additional features to the game. Such as objectives and stars from cards which add up to give you  a troop bonus.

This game is good to play with friends it makes it alot more interesting but does also destroy a few friendships for a couple of days which I found out. With friends this is perfect. With tactics and ruthlesness. If you betray your friend to win you have a few things going on .You either win or keep your friends. This game is a mix of Luck and Skill so be sure to use your brain when playing this game.

From a solo point of view the multiplayer is not great and you very rarely will find a lobby let alone people who will play with you. There is a campaign but this annoyed me as the first level is a tutorial and talks you through alot even tho I knew how to play so I gave up. But if you are new to risk I would encourage you to play this first.

This game is really worth it and should be a good addition to your steam library. This is a must with friends and is a whole lot of fun. Whenever this is on sale try to encourage your friends to buy it. The more the merryier(up to 5 players). This game mixes RISK(pardon the pun) and reward. Really worth it!

reviewText:
4/5 feral cats.

One of the few titles EA published right. This game is an electronic version of the popular board game called RISK. You control armies across a board which features a vast amount of territories to control and capture.

Choose to command one of the belligerents of the game such as the Feral cats, mighty British army, filthy undead, and Bill Gates robots. Not one of these has advantages over the other which allows a fair game. Though, if you really want to be unfair and have the upper hand, certain territories feature special add-ons for your territory allowing bonuses to come into effect.

These bonuses can range from placing airfields, artillery pieces, and an assortment of other bonuses which provide extra damage during the engagement process.

Mass huge armies by placing counters on territories and send them to wipe out everyone across the globe, capturing more territory as you go, allowing more income counters for troops. This game is extremely fun played with others and you will have a blast. The back-story for the four races in the game is rather humorous and well made. You won’t regret this purchase.

reviewText:
This game sucks.  I had another review and played it a bit more and changed my mind.  The RNG is horrable.  It is crazy streaky to rediculousness.  I mean how many times in a row will 2 die come up with the same number?  Try 9 times.  While that is the most I have happen, streaks for like 4 or 5 are not uncommon.

To make matters worse, is that it has a die rolling animation that is super slow.  You need to watch this with EACH DIE ROLL.  Huge stacks take forever.  There was some kind of quick thing, but it stopped doing that and I have no idea how to do faster rolls.  The UI is also kind of buggy, perhaps the dissapearance of the fast rolling is part of that.  The AI is pretty stupid as well.

The extra game modes do not add anything, as thier special rules are quite broken".  IE: There is the temple thing you can control that you can use once per turn that will not just kill an entire stack
date: but actually change the stack to your guys.  Someone just dropped a stack of 32 guys?  Thanks
hoursPlayed: they are mine now.  Of course the AI doesn't realise the god power here and just summons giant stacks for you to possess.  That is when it is not flooding its own stacks (another map feature) and killing its own men."

votesTotal: 29 of 53 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR
Neat for anyone who likes a simplified RISK to play with friends online, and doesn't want to wait an hour for decisions to be made.

Pros

Graphics
Simple

Cons

Drag and Click doesn't always select properly
RNG seems stupid at times

Gameplay
I've been meaning to learn RISK for a while. It was always one of those games that I saw and heard a lot about, but never quite got around to the stage of persuading people to sit around a table and play it. With RISK: Factions on steam, this problem is eliminated. If you have no clue whatsoever on how to play the game, this will give you a nice crash course, though the rules it offers with the Factions element are a lot more simplified than the normal rules. They also make the gameplay a lot faster.


It can be fiddly working with the faster drag and release methods to speed up troop fights. You can either watch fights happen, including each painstaking dice roll, or just speed through them. Sometimes it doesn't always work when selecting and choosing – and with smaller territories they can be hard to highlight. I've had quite a few incidents where I wanted to invade a specific territory, and it took me 20 or so tries before the area finally got highlighted.


The main campaign mode is designed basically to give you the rules on this version of the game, and introduce you to five “leaders” who each have their quirks. You also get the option to have the classic RISK map without the added faction goodies, a classic RISK map with them thrown in, and a faster win method, or utilising maps that showed throughout the campaign, with their specific objectives. You can control one of five leaders: McGutterpants, Generalissmo Meow, His Excellency, Gary, Commandant SixFour, or Colonal Stiffenberg, You can either take objectives on the map for extra bonuses within game, such as an enemy city or capital, or achieve something such as taking over 5 territories in one turn -- to gain advantages over the rest. I can guarantee RNG will annoy you a lot. It can be depressing to see your 10 troops fail to take over an country with only 2 troops defending. Such is the way of the RNG Gods.


The graphics are cartoonish and comical in nature. The faction leaders are funny, with their own animations and expressions for when they attack, lose land, and gain land. The maps themselves are easy to follow, and quite bright.


The music is alright, there's nothing I would find outstanding about it – same with the voice acting tailored to the faction leaders.


There's nothing particularly special about this game, but if you want to play RISK, learn the rules, and be able to play with friends online, then this is definitely worth some of your hours.


Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

reviewText:
The game is fun (it's Risk, not that hard to make fun) but the servers have some IMMENSE problems keeping a connection going. I was playing with my brother and twice in a row, once where he hosted, once where I hosted, we were forced to leave the game because it became unresponsive. Both times it happened mid command, leaving the one not hosting unable to do anything but exit.

That aside, playing against the AI is like playing against someone with a loaded dice. A mathematically impossible move (him defending with 1 against your 15 and winning) seems to be something it excels at.

The graphics are good and I think I'll take a deeper look into the campaign, but skirmishing agaist the AI can not be advised, and you risk losing a game due to it bugging out if you're playing online.

Maybe EA will release a Be able to finish a match" DLC for 19.99$ in the future
date: but I doubt it. EA keeping to their standards I suppose."

reviewText: Oh my, another RISK game. Well, dont get me wrong, its a good game overall. The multiplayer is dead, if you dont have anyone to play with then all you are going to do is finish the campaign and play 2-3 missions on Custom mode. Thats pretty much it, it doesn't have much going for it. The objectives are great and all, the animations are halirous and the cutscenes will give you a laugh or two, but the game doesn't have that original RISK feeling. If you are a fan of RISK and you have nothin' to do, sure, why not? I'd say you can finish the campaign in around 2-3 hours minimum, and the Custom mode is great. It will kill some hours and then you will probably never touch it again.\n\nMeh 3/5, would bang.

reviewText:
I can't believe all the positive reviews for this.. am I missing something?

The stupid slow dice animations etc drive me insane!  There is a slight fast forward option that you have to click for each opponent..   which is still a bit slow.. but there is no option to speed up your turn.  You have to watch drawn out crappy dice animations for every dice roll!

I've played a lot of risk games on computers.. the best version ever was one on an old Apple (before OSX) that concentrated on the strategy not crappy graphics and slow animations.

After you played risk a lot you don't want to watch dumb animations every turn.. you just want to action your move and do it instantly.

Worse version I've ever played.. other versions on steam had worse reviews so I'd hate to see how bad they are.  I should've got the demo first.

Slow, cumbersome and crappy.   It would take you 2 hours to play a 10 minute game if you could bear play it for that long.

reviewText: Cartoon graphics. No card or roll options; no expanded maps in classic gameplay. The 2 speed settings are 1.Just slow enough to annoying. or 2. Uselessly fast blurs and flashes of movement and attacks. The 90's version of the hasbro risk game (ahem, before EA bought them) was better in graphics, asthetics, had many larger maps, options on how to use your dice for each other, options to turn off sluggish animations, options to use increasing or set card reenforcements... It was a better game in every way. AND it's 10 years older... Risk Factions is a waste of money.

reviewText: How hard is it to have the bare elements of risk properly shown in a digital format? We have this simple game, not too much more complicated to create then chess, yet we have to keep trying recreate the wheel. I should feel like I am playing risk, but I feel like I am playing completely different game which laughably trying to relate to the Angry Birds crowds. Risk should be about old timey armies with muskets, while riding on hoarse back, not unfunny cats, and uninspired, cheaply made cartoons under the guise of quirky style. This game felt like a joke, a $10 joke.

reviewText: My opinions of the original Risk boardgame nonwithstanding, Risk: Factions is awfully ported from whatever platform it was initially released on. Graphical glitches galore, netcode so broken it can't even sustain a simple turn-based game without crashing and disconnecting. Aside from the fact that, as an improvement of Risk, it's fairly unimpressive, it's an absolute mess of a piece of software. If you're looking for a fun strategy game in the same vien, check out Small World 2. Like Risk: Factions, the port isn't great, but shines compared to this.

reviewText:
Things wrong with this game:

1. Complete lack of control over game parameters. This game gives you zero options for adjusting any in-game settings. You can't even do an actual manual placement of troops. You can pick your color, but that is really it.

2. Clearly unbalance combat algorithms and computer AI that work co-operatively against the player. The computer regularly had rolls that favored it enormously while also generating highly improbable rolls to disadvantage the player. I don't mind a challenge, but at least have that challenge based in the strategy of the AIs rather than obvious cheating.

3. Poorly designed user interface. Risk is a pretty simple game but this iteration makes it overly complex with frustrating controls.

Avoid this title.

reviewText:
I enjoy risk, and this game adds in a few extra gameplay mechanics as well, that keep it interesting.  That being said, you can still play regular risk.

The single player mode has some short little plotline stuff to it as well, that basically explains how the world winds up going to hell with these cartoonish factions reacting to a combination of mistakes and their own greed.

Overall, its a nice relaxing little board game.

reviewText: I love risk and I adore the graphical nature that this one includes. That said, I played a game with a friend on the hotseat multiplayer against an ai named Gary and we lost misserably. I don't want to sound like a poor looser(which I'm well aware that I do) but Gary attacked my territory with 30 troops on it with 4 and won without loosing a single troop. He then went on and attacked my friends territory of 34 and once again won without loosing a single troop. Now I realise that sometimes these things happen due to the luck of the dice" but for it to happen twice in a row without loosing a single troop shows a bit dice favoritism. It's still a great game but I wouldn't nessesarly recomened it for battling against a cpu. Between human oponets the dice rolls are a lot fairer so that's who I'd recomened you play against."

reviewText:
If you're a Risk junkie I'd say pick it up on sale but don't expect perfection.

I enjoyed the game for a while at first as it's an interesting new way to play the game of Risk. There are unusual challenges and a lot of extra strategy thrown in but they could have done a lot better overall.

The dice are the worst part of the game. You can have 50 guys attack a territory with 5 people in it and lose 20 of yours on a regular basis. I've lost 15 in a row attacking a 1 defender (no defense die) and the sad part is it happens at one point almost every game.

There's also no customization options, playing a classic game of Risk only allows you to have the trade-in option of the cards increasing by 5s every trade, which means it's pointless to even go for country bonuses because once they get to 10+ troops per trade it's only about taking eachother's cards. The factions part of the game is more fun but with the cheating of the dice described above it causes a ton of rage quits.

Wish they'd fix it or maybe even make a new version that's more polished and fair but I'm sure they won't. Not really recommended unless you really like Risk and find it for under $5.

reviewText: The idea is fantastic.  I like all the extra stuff, the various 'things' that you can capture to change the way the game plays.  The writing is humorous.  It's Risk plus a bit more.\n\nAnd then the problems.  The campaign was...an introduction to the various factions.  That's it.  You didn't get to pick sides.  You simply got to play as the new faction.  But what's different about each faction?  The animations and the color!  That's it.  It's RISK so I really don't ask for the factions to have different powers.  But the animations.  They're cute, they're funny, I think they're well done...until you've witnessed them for the 100th time.  You can make the dice go faster...by giving up the dice all together and committing fully to the attack.  Tired of the slow animations that were fun and cute for the first couple hours?  Well, you can speed up the animation where the computer takes over territories (that's the ONLY animation that speeds up when you hit fast forward).  Tired of that same message that says cities help your ability to draft new soldiers"?  Too bad.  The game will remind you EVERY TIME YOU TAKE A TERRITORY WITH A CITY
recommended: you're obviously too dumb to've got it the first 50 times it told you.  ^_^\n\nSo I got tired of the aniimations.  I'll play Classic RIsk!  I thought.  How could they screw that up?  That's been done before.  All the rules and the standard variat...oh
hoursPlayed: there are no variations... fine.  Aaaaaaaand then I get gang ♥♥♥♥♥.  I understand.  I get it.  I don't win Risk all the time.  But when I lose
voteText: because one of the AIs turns in three sets of cards
votesHelpful: and then...I'm still alive...I have a set...it's the draft phase but I CAN'T TURN IN THE SET because the game lagged (single player) and I clicked on the card menu
votesTotal: which closed the card menu...but then I open it back up and can't turn it in?  ♥♥♥♥ you Risk Factions.  ♥♥♥♥ you.\n\nOh
votesFunny: and the actual game controller controls are not properly reflected on the screen.  Really?  The developer can't even get the controls to be properly reflected on the screen?\n\nSo to summarize:  This game is like that pretty guy or girl that you've just scored a date with.  They're fun
column16: they seem to be everything you want.  That little thing they do that annoys you
column17: that's no big deal--until you discover that there are a lot of those "little things that annoy you"  I do think it's almost worth the $10 I paid for it.  I certainly got two or three good hours of enjoyment out of it--but I can't recommend it.  It seems like a solid game until you get under the hood and check it out."

reviewText: Really, really disappointed in this. Ultimately, still boils down to chance and once the steamrolling begins, it's very difficult to stop. One of those games where the person winning is having a blast, but the losers just want to slit their wrists. Risk is just too simplistic and there's a reason most of us grow out of it in gradeschool. Go play Civ or one of the good european board games.

reviewText:
If you're a Risk junkie I'd say pick it up on sale but don't expect perfection.

I enjoyed the game for a while at first as it's an interesting new way to play the game of Risk. There are unusual challenges and a lot of extra strategy thrown in but they could have done a lot better overall.

The dice are the worst part of the game. You can have 50 guys attack a territory with 5 people in it and lose 20 of yours on a regular basis. I've lost 15 in a row attacking a 1 defender (no defense die) and the sad part is it happens at one point almost every game.

There's also no customization options, playing a classic game of Risk only allows you to have the trade-in option of the cards increasing by 5s every trade, which means it's pointless to even go for country bonuses because once they get to 10+ troops per trade it's only about taking eachother's cards. The factions part of the game is more fun but with the cheating of the dice described above it causes a ton of rage quits.

Wish they'd fix it or maybe even make a new version that's more polished and fair but I'm sure they won't. Not really recommended unless you really like Risk and find it for under $5.

reviewText:
Personally my problem with this game is that the A.I is completely biased and will always ALWAYS attack me instead of the other A.I regardless of how powerful the other A.I are around it. And then to top that off I can attack an enemy that is only 1 unit strong with an army that is 8+ and lose the battle and my entire reinforcements for that round, then the A.I will of course attack me and take all my remaining territories.

Edit:
Alright let me make it really clear. After a few games of risk I should NOT be able to see the A.I using the EXACT SAME TACTIC over and over again!!! It got to the point where I was able to accurately predict exactly where the enemy was going to invade every single time. Let me also make something else clear, cards should not give you 40 UNITS AND ALLOW YOU TO TAKE OVER ALL OF EUROPE, AFRICA AND SOUTH AMERICA IN ONE TURN WHILE SIMUTANEOUSLY DESTROYING ALL OF THE ENEMIES STOCKPILED UNITS

Personally my problem with this game is that the A.I is completely biased and will always ALWAYS attack me instead of the other A.I regardless of how powerful the other A.I are around it. And then to top that off I can attack an enemy that is only 1 unit strong with an army that is 8+ and lose the battle and my entire reinforcements for that round, then the A.I will of course attack me and take all my remaining territories.

Edit:
Alright let me make it really clear. After a few games of risk I should NOT be able to see the A.I using the EXACT SAME TACTIC over and over again!!! It got to the point where I was able to accurately predict exactly where the enemy was going to invade every single time. Let me also make something else clear, cards should not give you 40 UNITS AND ALLOW YOU TO TAKE OVER ALL OF EUROPE, AFRICA AND SOUTH AMERICA IN ONE TURN WHILE SIMUTANEOUSLY DESTROYING ALL OF THE ENEMIES STOCKPILED UNITS

reviewText:
This game is so bad. Better said, this game has one of the worst rng factors I've ever stumbled across. Yeah I know, happens in real life risk too, but no one plays the game online anymore, so you'll only have the AI to play against. And this is where the ridiculous rng happens. Ever lost with 15 units against 1 pc unit rolling 10x 6 in a row? Yeah that's fun! Another example: I just lost a game because of only getting 1 card set done (right in the beginning for 6 units) the three AI enemies could each complete a card set every three turns two times in a row. It ended with me having 4 countries 3 units each against AI opponents each controlling a continent. But they didn't decide to weaken each other to deny their continent bonuses, but somehow they decided to crush themselves in North America. In the end I managed to conquer South America and then suddenly they decided to deny my bonuses.

TL;DR: Everytime you get realistic chances at winning the game, all AI opponents will leap on you together. When done, they will continue doing their thing. + bad rng dice rolls

If some of you are interested in my rolls:

1: 854
2: 849
3: 827
4: 803
5: 826
6: 769

1:6 deviation: +9%, 2:5 deviation: -10%, 3:4 deviation: -10,3%
After this amount of rolls it should start to get to zero deviation, but no.

reviewText: This game would be good if the dice system wasn't so broke.  I was winning by a lot, when I cashed in my cards for a pretty substantial haul.  I attacked a nation with 56 armies against 12. I lost and they still had 3 remaining.  Then just to get a card, I attacked a country with 60 armies to their 4 and I lost 46 armies.  That is pretty much how this game goes.  It is not worth the frustration.
